title.narrative: 1.2: COMMUNITY-BASED INTEGRATED EARLY CHILDHOOD CARE AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES

description.narrative: Communities in priority districts and regions have increased capacity to deliver community-based services, create demand and ensure accountability for integrated early childhood survival and development services., which contributes to Access To Quality Learning Opportunities, Access To Quality Learning Opportunities (Covid), Cross-Sectoral - Social And Behaviour Change, Early Detection And Treatment Of Malnutrition, Early Detection And Treatment Of Malnutrition (Covid), Fast-Track The End Of Hiv/Aids, Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence (Covid), Immunization Services As Part Of Primary Health Care, Nutrition In Early Childhood, Nutrition In Early Childhood (Covid), Nutrition Of Adolescents And Women, Strengthening Primary Health Care And High-Impact Health Interventions. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Data, Research, Evaluation And Knowledge Management, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Evaluations, Research And Data, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Harnessing Power Of Business And Markets, Innovation, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind, United Nations Working Together. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Young girls and boys (0â€“5 years), particularly the most deprived and hard-to-reach, are immunized, well nourished, healthy, protected, registered at birth and prepared for school, including in humanitarian situations.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Communities in priority districts and regions have increased capacity to deliver community-based services, create demand andensure accountability for integrated early childhood survival and development services.

description.narrative: In 2020, UNICEF technically and financially supported the finalization of the Multisectoral Nutrition Action Plan 2021-2024 (PAMN) which was validated and approved by the government. In addition, integrating nutrition into “PDSEC” has been initiated. Also, UNICEF technically supported the government to operationalize the digitization of community health. At the operational level, 657 new GSAN were established, trained, and equipped. 609,838 babysitters (152,460 men, 457,378 women) received advice on best practices for infant and young child feeding. 958 ASCs were trained on the IMAM. 2,594,373 children under five were screened for acute malnutrition at the community level. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:05/01/2022
